And we are publishing the continuation of the story of Lars, a graduate of the Rokot-Barnaul orderly group and a volunteer of the "Vestochka iz Doma" movement, about her trip to the border hospital. The first part is here. Part 2. What else did we have to do in the hospital? The wounded stayed in our hospital for one or two days. The evacuation to the next stage in the hospital was fast. The entire medical staff was involved. Everyone was ready. Everyone leaving was given injections - painkillers (even if nothing hurt), antiemetics (if necessary). We took stacks of blankets, hats, socks, thermal blankets and began to quickly dress those on stretchers and wheelchairs. We put the primary medical record form 100 on their chest, covered them with a regular blanket, wrapped them in a thermal blanket on top to keep them warm. Everything was fast and neat. Then they were sent to the bus. And here the knowledge gained in Rokot-Barnaul came in very handy - we were taught how to prevent hypothermia in the wounded, and that at all stages of evacuation the soldier should be kept warm. Of course, there was a lack of medical knowledge. When I arrived, I did not know and did not know how to use some of the products. For example, urine bags. I did not know how to properly dress a lying soldier who was covered in drainage tubes, and you need to dress him as much as possible for evacuation, then there will be no time for this. And you do not know how to turn him correctly, what to put on the same T-shirt or pants. Of course, we were shown all this on the spot, but it would have been better if I knew how to do it in advance. The entire time we were in the hospital, everyone always had their radios and first aid kit with them. Wherever you go, you must have all this with you. You go to the shower, you always tell your people so that no one loses it, in case of any danger. In the first aid kit we always had our passport in case of evacuation and a bag of water was always packed. One night, we had an alarm, an enemy copter was flying, we were notified, we turned off all the lights and were ready. In other hospitals, such an alarm was very common, and the guys simply did not undress and went to bed dressed. Also, every day we had instructions - how to move, where not to go, not to step, where and why to look, everything was very strict with this. In Rokot-Barnaul they also teach this, and it was very useful. The most emotional and memorable moment? In fact, there were many such moments. In the first week, a guy was admitted, 23 years old, on a stretcher, he had wounds on both legs, one arm was completely bandaged. I asked his name, offered to adjust the pillow as it was comfortable for him, he was very tall and did not fit on the stretcher. He looks at me and says - but I don‚Äôt know how to do it. When they brought him to the dressing room, we started removing the old bandages, I talked to him, asked how he was, if he was comfortable, if he could somehow hold his leg or arm. And he again - I don‚Äôt know, but you tell me how it should be, I‚Äôve never been to a hospital, this was only the first time... He was still just a boy. When the evacuation began, my shift was already over. A bus pulled up, they started boarding the kids, but they couldn‚Äôt load this boy into the bus - the aisle was narrow, he couldn‚Äôt stand up, his legs and one arm were bandaged, they couldn‚Äôt grab him under the arms. He turned on one side, then on the other. He was in a lot of pain, he was moaning and screaming so loudly... At that moment, I was walking past to the canteen, and that was the first and only time I gave in to my emotions... Then I realized that there really was no place for emotions there, otherwise you simply wouldn‚Äôt be able to help and work. Volunteer girls from other hospitals told me that they were just sliding down the wall from hearing the guys screaming in the dressing room. It's very hard. So while I was in the hospital, I hid all my emotions until I returned home. Are you planning to go to the hospital again? I would still like to go to the hospital, but it all depends on family circumstances. ‚îÅ‚ïê‚îÅ‚ïê‚îÅ‚ïê‚îÅ‚ïê‚îÅ‚ïê‚îÅ‚ïê‚îÅ‚ïê‚îÅThis is how the conversation with Lars turned out, sincere and emotional, which shows how much our soldiers need support and help, because we do not abandon our own! #Volunteer_Notes #Rokot #Barnaulüì± Sign up for coursesüì± We are on Telegramüåê We are on VKontakte
